greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of no-leg partitions of n having Durfee square of size k (n >= 1, 1 <= k <= floor(sqrt(n))). Also, number of no-arm partitions of n having Durfee square of size k.
comment: Given a partition P, the partition formed by the cells situated below the Durfee square of P is called the leg of P. Similarly, the partition formed by the cells situated to the right of the Durfee square of P is called the arm of P.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..1000, flattened
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Rogers-Ramanujan Identities
formula: Sum_{k>=0} k! * T(n,k) = A327710(n). - _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 25 2020
maple: G := add(t^k*x^(k^2)/mul(1-x^i, i = 1 .. k), k = 0 .. 80): Gser := simplify(series(G, x = 0,40)): for n to 35 do P[n] := sort(coeff(Gser, x, n)) end do: for n to 35 do seq(coeff(P[n], t, j), j = 1 .. degree(P[n])) end do; # yields sequence in triangular form
seq(seq(T(n, k), k=1..floor(sqrt(n))), n=1..30); # _Alois P. Heinz_, Jan 30 2016
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n==0, 1, If[i<1, 0, b[n, i-1] + If[i>n, 0, b[n-i, i]]]]; T[n_, k_] := b[n-k^2, k]; Table[T[n, k], {n, 1, 30}, {k, 1, Floor[Sqrt[n]]}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 10 2016 after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: tabf(nn) = for(n=1, nn, for(k=1, sqrtint(n), print1(T(n, k), ", ")); print) \\ _Seiichi Manyama_, Oct 14 2019
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 29 2016
